newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan devalues rupee 7.86 percent against dollar.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan devalues rupee 7.86 percent against dollar.

text.p: The State (central) Bank of Pakistan (SBP) devalued the rupee by 7.86 percent against the dollar on Tuesday after days of denying market rumours that such a step was imminent.
The SBP moved the rupee down to 40.1200/40.3206 to the dollar from 36.9700/37.1549. It last changed the rate on September 10, when a small downward adjustment was made.

The bank gave no immediate explanation for the move, widely seen as part of an economic rescue package agreed with the International Monetary Fund aimed at cutting Pakistan's budget deficit and bridging its yawning current account deficit.
Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government has yet to disclose the rest of the package, expected to include stringent spending cuts and the imposition of agricultural income tax.
An IMF mission is due to arrive in Pakistan on Thursday for a review of the economy that must be completed before the fund can release more money from a stalled $600 million standby loan.
